node.text: A student struggling with oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) can be disruptive to the class, but these strategies can help. 💗

node.title: Understanding and Supporting Your Student With ODD

node.text: Here are 4 mindsets teachers can adopt to reframe math as a creative, empowering tool that’s relevant to everyday life.

node.title: How to Ease Math Anxiety in the Classroom

node.text:
Distractions, confusing material, or an overwhelming amount of information can tax a student’s working memory. Here are tips that can help.

#WorkingMemory #ClassroomTips #TeacherTips #InTheClassroom #EducationResearch

node.title: How to Optimize Working Memory in the Classroom

node.text:
Getting to know all your students at the top of a school year can be overwhelming. One idea? Ask their families to tell you all about them, in a playful assignment called "In a Million Words or Less."

The Million Words activity originated with teacher Deb Bova on the MiddleWeb site in 2003, but has thousands of variations.

Link in bio. 

#FamilyEngagement #BackToSchool #StudentEngagement #BackToSchoolActivity #TeacherTip #TeacherTips

node.title: Getting to Know Your Students in a Million Words or Less

node.text:
As you return to school, think about starting a new routine or ritual that welcomes students to class every day. Not only will it help with classroom management, but students will be more focused, grounded, and ready to learn.

#WelcomeBack #BackToSchool #MorningRoutine #TeacherTip #TeachersOfInstagram

node.title: Starting Each Class With A Warm Welcome

node.text:
Educator Shana White discusses how she uses art to bring every student's identity into the classroom. "Identity portraits are a project that allows kids to express their own identities. It's a really big growth point for a lot of kids that they are able to be comfortable with who they are and recognize and respect the identity markers of anybody." 🖌

#Diversity #CulturallyResponsiveTeaching #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #Arts #ArtEducation

node.title: Exploring Perceptions About Identity Through Self-Portraits

node.text: How can you help your students become more independent learners? Give them tools to think metacognitively—and explore how their own brains work.

node.title: How to Foster Metacognitive Skills for Independent Learning

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on September 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Q: Should classroom participation be be graded or ungraded? edutopia'.

node.text: Should classroom participation be graded or ungraded? It's a question that generates a lot of debate—we'd love to know what you think.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Research- Backed Insights to Improve Engagement with Parents @edutopia'.

node.text:
These 7 research-backed insights can help you improve your engagement with parents.

#ParentEngagement #TeachrTips #TeacherTip #EducationResearch

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Research- Backed Insights to Improve Engagement with Parents @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Shift Your Mindset X arents are more likely to be partners in students learning when educators indicate that they believe in every child's potential- and show that they value the family's contribution-according to research. To foster a culture of trust and collaboration, interactions between teachers and parents should encourage parental input and focus more on hopes and opportunities for the student rather than missed work and mistakes. FanandWilliams,2009 @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Include Every Family S tudies show that most families want to volunteer or meet teachers in person, but work schedules and domestic obligations often prevent it. Don't ver-prioritize traditional parental involvement like fundraising or volunteering that may rely on scarce resources such as money and time. Instead, find other ways families can share their cultures, values, and ideas, like an open door policy, Zoom call, or parent breakfast with students. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Encourage and Support at-Home Learning roviding parents with clear explanations of academic content and goals, and making yourself accessible for questions, can lead to significant increases in students' test scores, according to research. Remind parents, too, of the subtler ways they can support learning at home, such as reading with their child, checking their child's homework, and making sure they have time to study. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'ç Use Nudges Effectively esearch has found that weekly text messages sent to parents of middle and high schoo students about course progress can reduce failures, while literacy tips sent via text to preschool families can lead to higher scores on end-of-year literacy assessments. Try reaching out to families regularly with simple messages by phone or text to raise student performance and boost engagement. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Incoporate Multimodal Communication inety-seven percent of Americans have a mobile phone, but schools often communicate with email only, which many families never read Survey parents early in the year to determine their preferred communication method, and try distributing key information through multiple platforms -paper, email, text, or phone call-to increase the likelihood that it's received. @edutopia'.

Photo by Edutopia on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Recognize Parent Diversity T en percent of American schoolchildren speak a language other than English and many other students come from families that speak varied languages at home. Use digital tools to translate school and classroom communication into families' languages-otherwise, you risk alienating them. Ensure that families' linguistic and cultural diversity is valued through recognition of holidays, for example, or diversity and inclusion training for staff. @edutopia'.

node.text:
A focused, quiet class is often a productive one. But the superficial appearance of a composed classroom can actually hide a deeper problem with student engagement by disguising disinterest or even boredom as attentiveness, veteran teachers tell us.

“My first piece of advice is not to be scared of a noisy classroom,” writes Heather Redmon Leise, a high school history and government teacher, via Facebook. “Let the side conversations happen while students are working, and eventually they will invite you in.”

Here are some ways to manage when and how students chat with each other in class:

⭐ Allow some frivolity: Teachers tell us that, in their well-managed classrooms, they allow students to take breaks and be silly at times, and give them frequent opportunities to connect.

⭐ Give them time to tell their stories: “One way we can deepen our relationships with students is to share a bit about ourselves with them, and create opportunities for them to share with us—and each other,” says Rebecca Alber, an instructor at UCLA’s Graduate School of Education.

⭐ You can start the period asking students if they have a good story to share, share one yourself, or pair students up. Sharing and listening helps students develop a deep sense of connection.

⭐  Bracket the class with unstructured time: Sometimes a 2- or 3-minute break can re-energize everyone. However, it’s important to model for students how this break will unfold and how they’ll return to their seats to focus once it concludes.

⭐ Challenge the conventional wisdom: Break out of the standard routine sometimes and make space for students to talk. “Classrooms should be vibrant and interesting, exciting places, and so I’m all for getting students up and moving and having fun,” says teacher and author Michael Linsin. “Those things just make classroom management stronger, and they free you to ask anything of your students, including silence.”

node.text:
We often think of parent engagement only as volunteering for the PTA, coaching the softball team, or chaperoning the middle school dance, which unfortunately leaves many parents feeling left out—or that they can't contribute to the school.

Teachers can help parents rethink engagement by explicitly communicating key responsibilities they have, such as taking an active role in helping their child learn to organize his or her study time. Parents can be encouraged to monitor engagement, limit distractions, build consistency, and celebrate periods of concentration. They can take time to discuss school matters with their child, asking questions about the school day: friends, concepts learned, struggles and discomforts, and successes and achievements.

When parents feel that they are a part of an inclusive learning culture and have a clear awareness of their role in their child’s learning, true partnerships can occur. - Louise El Yaafouri, Educator

#TeacherTip #TeacherTips #ParentParticipation #EnglishLanguageLearners #ELL #FamilyEngagement

node.text:
Timothy Shanahan was once a novice teacher doing round robin reading with his students—even though his professors in graduate school had strongly advised against it, and he had developed his own negative feelings about the practice.
⁣
“I used it because it kept the kids on task...and frankly, I didn’t know what else to do,” writes Shanahan, now a professor in Chicago.
⁣
Here are a few literacy practices to retire this year, followed by better options for budding readers:⁣
⁣
Reading logs: A 2012 study found that students who completed mandatory logs lost interest in recreational reading when compared to peers who logged reading voluntarily. Attitudes towards academic reading also declined significantly.
⁣
Turn-taking oral reading: Asking students to take turns reading out loud can “stigmatize poor readers, weaken comprehension, and sabotage fluency and pronunciation,” concludes educator Todd Finley, after surveying over 30 studies and articles on the topic.⁣
⁣
Prizes: Research shows that extrinsic motivators like stickers may actually decrease motivation to read. Instead, offer rewards that are closely aligned with the act of reading, like books they can keep for themselves.⁣
⁣
Better approaches...
⁣
Reading accountability partners: Partners discuss the previous day’s reading and hold each other accountable for completing it. Teacher Allie Thrower says it works best when she pairs students who challenge each other academically and encourage each other emotionally.
⁣
Choral reading: The teacher and class read a passage aloud together, reducing “struggling readers’ public exposure,” says Finley, while smoothing out individual fluency hiccups, and extending the length of the passages kids are exposed to.⁣
⁣
Scaffolded silent reading: We fail to prepare students for silent reading and are “shocked when they lose interest,” writes educator Rebecca Alber. Consider pre-teaching vocabulary and providing a plot overview before silent reading.
⁣
Teacher read-alouds: Read to the class for 5-7 minutes daily, says teacher Christie Rodgers, stopping frequently to wonder aloud and show students what good readers do when they are tripped up by a word or a challenging passage.

node.text:
Every Friday, some students in Modesto, California aren’t met by a big yellow school bus, but by the smiling faces of their teachers and support staff who walk them to school.

Staff from Bret Harte Elementary School and Hanshaw Middle School meet at the elementary school for a light breakfast, and then by 7:35 AM, they begin walking to meet students. While some families find the group along the way, pulling over in the car to let their children join in, others are assisted with crossing the street or even welcomed with a friendly knock on their front door in the morning. Between 25 to more than 100 families, students, and staff participate, on average, each Friday.

According to Bret Harte Principal Marla Conteh, the initiative has not only helped improve attendance, but has bolstered the relationship with the surrounding community. 

“Our Bret Harte staff wanted to connect with families and scholars on a more personal level and walking to school together was the perfect way to make this happen,” said Conteh. “We hope our Peace Path will promote wellness, scholar attendance will increase, and families will feel valued and welcomed by our Bret Harte staff.”

#BackToSchool #WalkingToSchool #WalkToSchool #TeachersOfInstagram #EducationNews
